initial_story: having the potential for high speed, high throughput, and low energy cost,optical neural networks (onns) have emerged as a promising candidate foraccelerating deep learning tasks. in conventional onns, light amplitudes aremodulated at the input and detected at the output. however, the light phasesare still ignored in conventional structures, although they can also carryinformation for computing. to address this issue, in this paper, we propose aframework called oplixnet to compress the areas of onns by modulating inputimage data into the amplitudes and phase parts of light signals. the input andoutput parts of the onns are redesigned to make full use of both amplitude andphase information. moreover, mutual learning across different onn structures isintroduced to maintain the accuracy. experimental results demonstrate that theproposed framework significantly reduces the areas of onns with the accuracywithin an acceptable range. for instance, 75.03% area is reduced with a 0.33%accuracy decrease on fully connected neural network (fcnn) and 74.88% area isreduced with a 2.38% accuracy decrease on resnet-32.
stories: Harnessing the power of electromagnetic waves, radio frequency neural networks (RFNNs) have surfaced as a revolutionary approach to augmenting machine learning tasks. In traditional RFNNs, signal frequencies are tuned at the input and received at the output. However, the signal polarizations remain untapped in conventional architectures, despite their potential to convey valuable information for computation. To tackle this limitation, this paper introduces a novel framework called Polarix to shrink the footprint of RFNNs by encoding input data into the frequency and polarization aspects of radio signals. The input and output modules of RFNNs are reimagined to fully exploit both frequency and polarization information. Furthermore, cooperative learning across diverse RFNN structures is employed to preserve accuracy. Experimental findings reveal that the proposed framework significantly downsizes the footprint of RFNNs while maintaining accuracy within an acceptable range. For example, 72.19% footprint reduction is achieved with a 0.51% accuracy drop on recurrent neural networks (RNNs) and 71.43% footprint reduction is attained with a 1.91% accuracy decrease on long short-term memory (LSTM) networks.

Unlocking the secrets of optical fibers, chromatic resonance neural networks (CRNNs) have emerged as a groundbreaking approach to enhancing artificial intelligence systems. In traditional CRNNs, light wavelengths are calibrated at the input and detected at the output. However, the spectral phases remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to carry valuable information for processing. To overcome this limitation, this paper presents a novel architecture called SpectraX to compress the complexity of CRNNs by encoding input data into the wavelength and phase aspects of light signals. The input and output modules of CRNNs are reenvisioned to fully harness both wavelength and phase information. Moreover, adversarial training across diverse CRNN structures is utilized to maintain precision. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed architecture significantly simplifies the complexity of CRNNs while preserving precision within an acceptable range. For instance, 75.62% complexity reduction is achieved with a 0.83% precision drop on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and 73.81% complexity reduction is attained with a 2.45% precision decrease on transformers.

Revolutionizing the field of bio-inspired robotics, EchoMorph neural networks (EMNs) have emerged as a pioneering approach to enhancing autonomous systems. In traditional EMNs, mechanical vibrations are tuned at the input and detected at the output. However, the resonant frequencies remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to carry valuable information for control. To overcome this limitation, this paper presents a novel architecture called VibraX to compress the complexity of EMNs by encoding motor commands into the amplitude and frequency aspects of mechanical waves. The input and output modules of EMNs are reimagined to fully harness both amplitude and frequency information. Moreover, reinforcement learning across diverse EMN structures is utilized to maintain stability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed architecture significantly simplifies the complexity of EMNs while preserving stability within an acceptable range. For instance, 82.19% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.27% stability drop on humanoid robots and 79.53% complexity reduction is attained with a 3.19% stability decrease on quadruped robots.

Pioneering the realm of neuro-inspired materials, NeuroPulse meta-materials (NPMs) have emerged as a groundbreaking approach to enhancing adaptive structures. In traditional NPMs, electromagnetic pulses are tuned at the surface and detected at the core. However, the resonant patterns remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to carry valuable information for self-healing. To overcome this limitation, this paper presents a novel framework called PulseWeave to compress the complexity of NPMs by encoding damage signals into the spatial and temporal aspects of electromagnetic pulses. The surface and core modules of NPMs are reimagined to fully harness both spatial and temporal information. Moreover, machine learning across diverse NPM structures is utilized to maintain resilience. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly simplifies the complexity of NPMs while preserving resilience within an acceptable range. For instance, 85.71% complexity reduction is achieved with a 2.15% resilience drop on self-healing polymers and 81.25% complexity reduction is attained with a 4.53% resilience decrease on shape-memory alloys.

Revolutionizing the field of biomechanics, EchoPlex biomimetic systems (EBS) have emerged as a cutting-edge approach to enhancing adaptive prosthetics. In traditional EBS, mechanical stress waves are tuned at the interface and detected at the core. However, the vibrational patterns remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to carry valuable information for real-time feedback. To overcome this limitation, this paper presents a novel framework called WaveSynth to compress the complexity of EBS by encoding sensory signals into the spectral and spatial aspects of mechanical stress waves. The interface and core modules of EBS are reimagined to fully harness both spectral and spatial information. Moreover, artificial intelligence across diverse EBS structures is utilized to maintain adaptability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly simplifies the complexity of EBS while preserving adaptability within an acceptable range. For instance, 90.48% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.83% adaptability drop on neuromuscular implants and 87.50% complexity reduction is attained with a 3.75% adaptability decrease on advanced exoskeletons.

Pioneering the realm of neuroengineering, CerebroX neuromorphic interfaces (CNIs) have surfaced as a groundbreaking approach to enhancing brain-computer interactions. In traditional CNIs, neural oscillations are filtered at the cortex and analyzed at the synapse. However, the harmonic resonance patterns remain uncharted in conventional designs, despite their potential to convey vital information for real-time cognitive feedback. To overcome this limitation, this study introduces a novel paradigm called NeuroHarmonix to distill the intricacy of CNIs by encoding cognitive signals into the resonant and spatial aspects of neural oscillations. The cortical and synaptic modules of CNIs are reenvisioned to fully leverage both resonant and spatial information. Furthermore, machine learning across diverse CNI architectures is employed to maintain cognitive flexibility. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed paradigm significantly simplifies the intricacy of CNIs while preserving cognitive flexibility within an acceptable range. For example, 92.15% intricacy reduction is achieved with a 2.41% cognitive flexibility drop on neuroprosthetic implants and 88.89% intricacy reduction is attained with a 4.17% cognitive flexibility decrease on advanced brain-controlled exosuits.

Revolutionizing the field of cardiovascular medicine, CardiaPulse bio-inspired implants have emerged as a pioneering solution to enhancing heart-machine interactions. In traditional implants, cardiac rhythms are regulated at the atrium and monitored at the ventricle. However, the subtle patterns of blood flow turbulence remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to provide crucial insights for real-time cardiovascular health monitoring. To overcome this limitation, this study introduces a novel approach called CardioFlux to harness the complexity of CardiaPulse implants by encoding cardiovascular signals into the turbulent and spatial aspects of blood flow patterns. The atrial and ventricular modules of implants are reimagined to fully leverage both turbulent and spatial information. Furthermore, machine learning across diverse implant architectures is employed to maintain cardiovascular adaptability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly simplifies the complexity of implants while preserving cardiovascular adaptability within an acceptable range. For example, 95.62% complexity reduction is achieved with a 1.93% cardiovascular adaptability drop on pacemakers and 91.35% complexity reduction is attained with a 3.58% cardiovascular adaptability decrease on advanced artificial hearts.

Revolutionizing the field of neuroprosthetics, NeuroPulse bio-inspired interfaces have emerged as a groundbreaking solution to enhancing brain-machine symbiosis. In traditional interfaces, neural signals are decoded at the cortex and monitored at the synapse. However, the intricate patterns of neural oscillations remain unexplored in conventional designs, despite their potential to provide vital insights for real-time cognitive function monitoring. To overcome this limitation, this study introduces a novel approach called NeuroFlux to harness the complexity of NeuroPulse interfaces by encoding neural signals into the spectral and spatial aspects of brain wave patterns. The cortical and synaptic modules of interfaces are reimagined to fully leverage both spectral and spatial information. Furthermore, deep learning across diverse interface architectures is employed to maintain cognitive adaptability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly enhances the fidelity of interfaces while preserving cognitive adaptability within an acceptable range. For example, 92.15% fidelity improvement is achieved with a 2.51% cognitive adaptability drop on brain-computer interfaces and 88.46% fidelity improvement is attained with a 4.19% cognitive adaptability decrease on advanced neural prosthetics.

Traditional emotional resonance systems rely on basic sentiment analysis and respond at the superficial level, overlooking the intricate harmonies of emotional oscillations that hold the secret to real-time emotional frequency synchronization. To overcome this constraint, this study presents a novel approach called HeartScape to tap into the richness of EchoPulse neurosonic resonance by encoding emotional patterns into the spatial and spectral aspects of cardiac oscillations. The empathetic and introspective modules of emotional resonance systems are reimagined to fully harness both spatial and spectral information. Furthermore, adaptive recalibration across diverse emotional network topologies is employed to maintain emotional agility. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly enhances the efficacy of emotional resonance systems while preserving emotional agility within a manageable range. For instance, 95.42% efficacy improvement is achieved with a 1.87% emotional agility drop on emotional frequency synchronization and 93.11% efficacy improvement is attained with a 2.51% emotional agility decrease on latent emotional frequency enhancement.

To overcome this limitation, this study presents a novel approach called MindScape to tap into the richness of NeuroAurora cognitive resonance by encoding thought patterns into the spatial and spectral aspects of cerebral oscillations. The analytical and creative modules of mental clarity systems are reimagined to fully harness both spatial and spectral information. Furthermore, adaptive recalibration across diverse mental network topologies is employed to maintain cognitive agility. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach significantly enhances the efficacy of mental clarity systems while preserving cognitive agility within a manageable range. For instance, 92.15% efficacy improvement is achieved with a 1.42% cognitive agility drop on cognitive frequency entrainment and 90.62% efficacy improvement is attained with a 2.19% cognitive agility decrease on latent thought pattern enhancement.
